overview: The student will conduct an original research project in a research laboratory under supervision of a research scientist at the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute from February to November.The student will be introduced to current literature and techniques in specialised areas.The research project will form part of a larger project or the basis of an expanded project. In both cases the work is anticipated to culminate in an original research publication.
intended learning outcomes: Acquire the ability to absorb information, analyse it critically, and integrate it into the current state of knowledge in the field. Develop hypothesis, propose experiments, engage in discussion with other scientists.
Acquire and hone experimental skills for work at the bench. Acquire technical knowledge specific to the research project.
Acquire oral and written presentation skills to present original scientific data to an expert audience.
Generate a body of original scientific results that will form part of a peer-reviewed, primary research publication.

assessments.description: Oral overview of thesis project and literature
A written report (thesis) of up to 10,000 words, and an oral defense of the thesis. 10,000 words
Oral presentation of thesis results and response to questions
assessments.timing: In November after written thesis submission

assessments.description: Supervisor's input into Honours project assessment

Semester 1 (Early-Start).Contact hours: This subject is an individual research project and weekly contact hours will vary depending on the nature of the project.

Semester 2.Contact hours: This subject is an individual research project and weekly contact hours will vary depending on the nature of the project.

Available to Study Abroad and/or Study E: This subject is available to students studying at the University from eligible overseas institutions on exchange and study abroad. Students are required to satisfy any listed requirements, such as pre- and co-requisites, for enrolment in the subject.
